change.item: Encoded in EAD by Gregory Wiedeman

change.date: Additional materials arranged and described by Andrea Lurie

repository.corpname: M.E. Grenander Department of Special Collections & Archives

did.abstract: The collection pertains to the Women's movement during the 1960s-1980s, with an emphasis on LGBTQ+ women. Other subjects of interest include the experiences of working and professional women, and women who either worked in, or attended institutions of higher education. Many items in the collection are focused on women in the Capital Region of New York State.
did.physloc: The materials are located onsite in the department.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Initially processed in 2006 by Amy C. Schindler. Later acquisitions processed in 2022 by Andrea Lurie.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: Access to this record group is unrestricted.

userestrict.head: Copyright
userestrict.p: The researcher assumes full responsibility for conforming with the laws of copyright. Whenever possible, the M.E. Grenander Department of Special Collections and Archives will provide information about copyright owners and other restrictions, but the legal determination ultimately rests with the researcher. Requests for permission to publish material from this collection should be discussed with the Head of Special Collections and Archives.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: All items in this manuscript group were donated to the University Libraries, M.E. Grenander Department of Special Collections and Archives in 2004 and 2021 by Gloria DeSole and Meredith Butler.

bioghist.head: Biographical History
bioghist.p: Born in 1937, Gloria DeSole is a former employee of the University at Albany, having served as the senior adviser to the President for Affirmative Action and Employment Planning and Director of Affirmative Action from 1982 to 2000. Before DeSole's retirement, she was awarded the President's Undergraduate Leadership Award. During her term of service, DeSole expanded opportunities for women and minority faculty, staff and students. Prior to joining SUNY Albany in 1976, DeSole was an English professor at Skidmore College. She obtained her B.A. in 1959, and her Ph.D. in 1969, both from SUNY Albany. She also earned a master's degree from Columbia University. Other awards she has received during her career and dedication to social activism include the UAlbany's President's Lifetime Justice Award and the Harvey Milk Award for her activism for the LGBTQ+ community.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection is comprised of materials related to the women's movement, lesbian culture, and the experiences of professional women in the workplace. The bulk of materials are publications of academic and cultural journals. Also included are drafts of speeches created by Gloria DeSole, and notes on local organizations that served women in the Capital District. Also present in the collection is a copy of a master's thesis.

arrangement.head: Arrangement of the Collection
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged alphabetically. There are no series.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Preferred citation for this material is as follows:

Identification of specific item, series, box, folder, Gloria DeSole Papers, 1969-1988. M.E. Grenander Department of Special Collections and Archives, University Libraries, University at Albany, State University of New York (hereafter referred to as the DeSole Papers).

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: The following collections at the M.E. Grenander Department of Special Collections and Archives are related to the Gloria DeSole Papers: Caucus on Women's Rights at SUNY, Albany Chapter Records, 1970-1976, Joan Schultz Papers, ca. 1968-1980, Judith Fetterley Papers, 1971-1993, National Organization for Women â€“ Albany, N.Y. Chapter Records, 1971-2005, and National Organization for Women (NOW), New York State Chapter Records, 1961-2011. Additional related collections can be found at the subject pages for Women, Human Sexuality and Gender Identity, and Education.

did.unittitle: "Feminism in the Seventies: A Study of the Womens Liberation Movement of Albany, New York, 1969-1979," Margaret Boys, MA Thesis, Goddard College
